{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3688091,"name":"eli","username":"_monkey","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/_/d07c76/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-23T21:23:11.105Z","cooked":"

I’m using a RoboRIO 1 (everything updated to 2025) and when I run deploy, I get this error:

  • Failed to find HMB.Config register, status code -63195 ﻿
    ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿ terminate called after throwing an instance of ‘std::bad_alloc’ ﻿
    ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿ what(): std::bad_alloc

I’m currently trying to set up the USB stick, it’s got 16GB so I’m pretty sure it’s formatted in 32FAT, and I have the build.gradle commands from the garbage collection page on the FIRST website.

The software I’m using a very slightly modded version of the 2025 AdvantageScope KitBot Template. The heap size is no more than 140MB and I have disabled the system web server.

Can you try reimaging your roborio again, and then try a stock wpilib project without advantagekit? That error is a bit weird, kind of making it seem like there might be some other issue. Worth trying out to see at least.

I have previous 2025 code which worked on it (up to the most recent date), the reason I used the 2025 KitBot code was so I could learn how to do AdvantageScope logging.

Are you meaning advantagekit or advantagescope? They’re different things. And in general, AdvantageKit on a rio 1 is likely not going to work anymore.

Thad_House:

AdvantageKit on a rio 1 is likely not going to work anymore

All of the AdvantageKit template projects have been tested on the RIO 1 and should not cause memory issues on their own, though of course some care is required with any robot project of reasonable complexity. 6328 has frequently run the KitBot and differential drive templates on RIO 1s during the season.

Can you try running with the default garbage collection configuration from the template? It looks like your code includes the extra configuration options that should only be enabled on the RIO 2 (see the setup docs).

github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit

template_projects/template/build.gradle

da50d3548 

      
    
          
  1. frcJava(getArtifactTypeClass('FRCJavaArtifact')) {
    2. 
          
  2.     jvmArgs.add("-XX:+UnlockExperimentalVMOptions")
    3. 
          
  3.     jvmArgs.add("-XX:GCTimeRatio=5")
    4. 
          
  4.     jvmArgs.add("-XX:+UseSerialGC")
    5. 
          
  5.     jvmArgs.add("-XX:MaxGCPauseMillis=50")
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
  7.     // The options below may improve performance, but should only be enabled on the RIO 2
    8. 
          
  8.     //
    9. 
          
  9.     // final MAX_JAVA_HEAP_SIZE_MB = 100;
    10. 
          
  10.     // jvmArgs.add("-Xmx" + MAX_JAVA_HEAP_SIZE_MB + "M")
    11. 
          
  11.     // jvmArgs.add("-Xms" + MAX_JAVA_HEAP_SIZE_MB + "M")
    12. 
          
  12.     // jvmArgs.add("-XX:+AlwaysPreTouch")
    13. 
          
  13. }
    14.

OK, this is a different error which is specifically related to the new code you added. The end of the error links to the documentation page on stacktraces here, which should help you parse exactly where the issue is (the specific line numbers are part of the stacktrace). It particular, it looks like you may need to check that your subsystems and commands are being initialized in the right order.

My team’s old software lead helped me out and it turns out I just cast the flipperSubsystem class wrong in the RobotContainer, I put in:

private static FlipperSubsystem flipperSubsystem;

instead of:

private final FlipperSubsystem flipperSubsystem = new FlipperSubsystem();

after removing all of the “RoboRIO 2” optimizations in build.gradle and removing the code which rerouted stuff to a USB thumb drive in the RIO, as well as making the software changes, the code deployed just fine and works as intended.
